Payment arrangement allowing debts to be paid over time. Dutch tax authorities and other government agencies may allow installment payments for large debts or financial difficulties.
Government subsidies to help with living costs. Dutch allowances include housing allowance, healthcare allowance, and child benefits for eligible residents.
Government subsidy to help low-income residents pay rent. Dutch housing allowance reduces rental costs for eligible families and individuals.
Government subsidy to help low-income residents pay for health insurance. Dutch healthcare allowance reduces the cost of mandatory health insurance premiums.
Government subsidy to help working parents pay for childcare. Dutch childcare allowance reduces the cost of daycare and after-school care for eligible families.
Formal protest against a government decision or action. Dutch residents can file objections against various administrative decisions through legal procedures.
Organization that handles complaints about discrimination and promotes equal treatment. Dutch anti-discrimination offices provide advice, support, and legal assistance for discrimination cases.
Government service providing free legal advice and information. Dutch legal counters help residents understand their rights and provide guidance on legal matters.
Professional office where lawyers provide legal services and representation. Dutch law firms offer various legal services including immigration, family law, and civil matters.
Financial institution that provides banking services including accounts, loans, and financial advice. Dutch banks offer various services for individuals and businesses.
Financial account held at a bank for depositing and withdrawing money. Dutch bank accounts are essential for receiving salary, paying bills, and managing daily finances.
Plastic card used to access bank accounts and make payments. Dutch bank cards can be used for ATM withdrawals, point-of-sale purchases, and online banking.
System allowing regular payments to be made automatically from a bank account. Dutch banks offer automatic payment services for recurring bills like rent, utilities, and insurance.
Online banking services accessible through the internet. Dutch banks provide secure internet banking for managing accounts, transferring money, and paying bills from home.
Insurance coverage for medical expenses and healthcare services. Dutch health insurance is mandatory and covers essential care including doctor visits and hospital stays.
Insurance coverage for motor vehicles and related risks. Dutch car insurance is mandatory and covers damage, liability, and other vehicle-related incidents.
Regular payment for insurance coverage. Dutch insurance premiums vary by provider and coverage level, with options for monthly or annual payments.
Insurance coverage for legal responsibility for damage or injury to others. Dutch liability insurance protects individuals and businesses from financial consequences of accidents.
Insurance coverage for damage caused by fire and related perils. Dutch fire insurance protects homes and businesses from fire-related losses and damage.
Insurance coverage for travel-related risks and emergencies. Dutch travel insurance covers medical expenses, trip cancellation, lost luggage, and other travel-related incidents.
Harm or loss caused to property, people, or interests. Dutch insurance policies cover various types of damage including property damage, personal injury, and financial losses.

Core principle that everyone, including the government, must obey the law. Dutch democracy is built on this foundation, ensuring that power is not abused and citizens are protected by independent judges.
Official rules that everyone in the Netherlands must follow. Dutch laws are created by elected representatives and enforced by independent courts to maintain order and protect rights.
Most important law establishing the fundamental structure of Dutch government and citizens' rights. The Dutch constitution guarantees basic freedoms and sets the framework for democracy.
Constitutional right allowing citizens to express opinions freely. This fundamental Dutch value enables open discussion and debate, though it comes with responsibility to respect others.
Constitutional right guaranteeing religious freedom for all citizens. Dutch law protects the right to practice any religion or no religion, with government remaining neutral on religious matters.
Constitutional right allowing parents to choose their children's education. Dutch law supports both public and religious schools, giving families freedom in educational choices.

cards.front: Scheiding tussen de wet en religie
cards.description: Principle ensuring that secular laws take precedence over religious rules. Dutch society maintains this separation, with government decisions based on law rather than religious doctrine.
Monetary penalty for violating laws or regulations. Dutch authorities impose fines for various offenses, with amounts varying based on the severity of the violation.
Correctional facility where convicted criminals serve their sentences. Dutch prisons focus on rehabilitation and reintegration, preparing inmates for successful return to society.
Organization providing support and assistance to crime victims. Dutch victim support services offer emotional support, practical help, and guidance through legal processes.
Constitutional principle dividing government authority into three branches. Dutch democracy maintains separate legislative, executive, and judicial branches to prevent concentration of power.
Branch of government responsible for implementing and enforcing laws. Dutch executive power includes the King, Prime Minister, and cabinet ministers who run government departments.
Branch of government responsible for making laws. Dutch legislative power resides in the Parliament (Tweede Kamer and Eerste Kamer) which debates and votes on proposed legislation.
Branch of government responsible for interpreting laws and administering justice. Dutch courts are independent and ensure that laws are applied fairly and consistently.
Executive branch responsible for running the country and implementing policies. Dutch government consists of the King, Prime Minister, and cabinet ministers who manage various policy areas.
Head of state and symbol of national unity in the Netherlands. Dutch kings have ceremonial and symbolic roles, with actual governing power resting with elected officials.
Head of government and leader of the cabinet. Dutch Prime Ministers coordinate government policy, represent the country internationally, and lead the executive branch.
Government officials responsible for specific policy areas. Dutch ministers head government departments and implement policies in areas like education, healthcare, and transportation.
Upper house of the Dutch Parliament with 75 members. The Eerste Kamer reviews and approves legislation passed by the lower house, providing additional oversight.
Lower house of the Dutch Parliament with 150 elected members. The Tweede Kamer is the main legislative body where laws are debated, amended, and voted upon.
National legislative body consisting of the First and Second Chambers. Dutch Parliament is the highest democratic institution where elected representatives make laws and oversee government.
Legal professionals who preside over court proceedings and make judicial decisions. Dutch judges are independent and ensure that laws are applied fairly and consistently.
System of government where power comes from the people through elections. Dutch democracy features regular elections, multiple political parties, and protection of minority rights.
Form of government with a monarch as head of state. The Netherlands is a constitutional monarchy where the King has ceremonial duties while elected officials govern.
Principle that government power is limited by law and constitution. Dutch governance operates under this principle, ensuring that all authority is subject to legal constraints.
Fundamental law establishing the structure and principles of Dutch government. The constitution defines the relationship between government branches and protects citizens' rights.
Process of choosing government representatives through voting. Dutch elections are held regularly for various government levels, ensuring democratic representation.
Constitutional right to participate in elections. Dutch citizens aged 18 and older have the right to vote in national, provincial, and municipal elections.
Right to cast votes in elections. Dutch active voting rights allow citizens to participate in choosing their representatives at all government levels.
Right to stand as a candidate in elections. Dutch passive voting rights allow citizens to run for political office and represent their communities.
Central government responsible for national policies and administration. Dutch national government handles issues like defense, foreign policy, and national legislation.
National elections for the lower house of Parliament. Dutch Second Chamber elections determine the composition of the main legislative body and influence government formation.
Regional administrative divisions of the Netherlands. Dutch provinces handle regional planning, transportation, and coordination between municipalities.
Local government units responsible for local services and administration. Dutch municipalities handle housing, waste collection, local permits, and social support.
Regional organizations responsible for water management and flood protection. Dutch water boards manage dikes, canals, and water quality in their regions.
Political and economic union of European countries. The Netherlands is a member of the EU, participating in European decision-making and benefiting from European cooperation.
Direct vote by citizens on a specific political question. Dutch referendums allow citizens to directly participate in decision-making on important issues.
Head of government and leader of the cabinet. Dutch Prime Ministers coordinate government policy, represent the country internationally, and lead the executive branch.
Government official assisting ministers in specific policy areas. Dutch State Secretaries work under ministers and may have their own areas of responsibility.
Group of ministers and state secretaries who form the government. Dutch cabinets are formed after elections and are responsible for implementing government policy.
The Dutch parliament consists of the Senate (Eerste Kamer) and House of Representatives (Tweede Kamer). It's where laws are debated, amended, and passed.
The representative of the national government in each province. They chair the provincial executive and ensure national policies are implemented at the provincial level.
The systematic planning of land use and development. Dutch planologie ensures efficient use of limited space, balancing housing, nature, agriculture, and infrastructure needs.
The elected body that represents citizens at the local level. Dutch municipal councils make decisions about local services, housing, and community development.
The head of a municipality appointed by the national government. Dutch mayors chair the municipal executive and represent the municipality officially.
Administrative divisions within larger cities. Dutch deelgemeenten have their own councils and handle local matters while remaining part of the main municipality.
The elected council of a deelgemeente. These councils handle local issues within their area while working under the main municipal government.
The executive branch of the European Union. The Dutch government works with the European Commission to implement EU policies and regulations.
Annual speech by the Dutch king on Prinsjesdag (Prince's Day) outlining government plans for the coming year. This tradition marks the opening of the parliamentary year.
Political ideology favoring traditional values, limited government intervention, and free market economics. Dutch right-wing parties often focus on economic liberalism and social conservatism.

Political ideology favoring social equality, government intervention for social welfare, and progressive social policies. Dutch left-wing parties often focus on social justice and environmental protection.
Political stance favoring social reform, modernization, and forward-thinking policies. Dutch progressive parties often advocate for environmental protection, social equality, and innovation.
Political stance favoring traditional values, social stability, and gradual change. Dutch conservative parties often emphasize family values, law and order, and economic stability.
The person at the top of a political party's candidate list during elections. Dutch lijsttrekkers are the public face of their party and often become ministers if their party joins the government.
The location where citizens go to vote in elections. Dutch stembureaus are usually set up in schools, community centers, or other public buildings on election days.
The paper on which voters mark their choice in elections. Dutch stembiljetten are counted by hand to ensure transparency and accuracy in the democratic process.
More than half of the votes or seats. Dutch governments need a parliamentary majority to pass laws and implement policies effectively.
Political parties that together have more than half of the parliamentary seats. Dutch majority parties form coalitions to govern the country.
An alliance of political parties that work together to form a government. Dutch coalitions are necessary because no single party usually wins an absolute majority in elections.
Political parties that are not part of the governing coalition. Dutch opposition parties criticize government policies and offer alternative solutions.
The Dutch war of independence against Spanish rule (1568-1648). This conflict led to the establishment of the Dutch Republic and shaped Dutch national identity and values of freedom and tolerance.
Spanish king who ruled the Netherlands during the 16th century. His harsh policies and religious persecution led to the Dutch revolt and the Eighty Years' War for independence.
Members of the Protestant Christian faith. In Dutch history, Protestantism became widespread during the Reformation and played a key role in the fight for religious freedom.
Known as 'Father of the Fatherland', he led the Dutch revolt against Spanish rule. His leadership was crucial in establishing Dutch independence and the Republic.
The Dutch national anthem, written during the Eighty Years' War. It tells the story of William of Orange and his loyalty to the Dutch people, making it the oldest national anthem still in use.

cards.back: Republic of the Seven United Netherlands
cards.description: The Dutch Republic that existed from 1588 to 1795. This was a unique form of government for its time, combining elements of democracy and federalism, and marked the beginning of modern Dutch democracy.
Period of Dutch prosperity in the 17th century. The Netherlands became a global trading power, leading in art, science, and commerce, with figures like Rembrandt and the VOC.

The world's first multinational corporation, established in 1602. The VOC dominated global trade, particularly in spices from Asia, and played a crucial role in Dutch economic success during the Golden Age.
Period of rapid industrialization in the 19th century. The Netherlands experienced significant social and economic changes as traditional agriculture gave way to modern industry and urbanization.

Political movement advocating for workers' rights and social equality. Dutch socialists played a key role in establishing social welfare programs and improving working conditions in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
Dutch queen who reigned from 1890 to 1948. She became a symbol of Dutch resistance during World War II, leading the government-in-exile from London and maintaining Dutch morale.
The Dutch resistance movement during World War II. Dutch citizens organized underground networks to help Jews, hide Allied pilots, and sabotage German operations, showing courage and solidarity.
The day the Netherlands was liberated from German occupation. This date is celebrated annually as Bevrijdingsdag (Liberation Day), commemorating freedom and honoring those who fought for it.

The devastating flood of 1953 that caused massive destruction in the Netherlands. This disaster led to the Delta Plan, a comprehensive system of dams and storm surge barriers to protect against future floods.

Massive engineering project to protect the Netherlands from flooding. After the 1953 flood, this plan created a system of dams, sluices, and storm surge barriers, making the country one of the safest from flooding in the world.
The actual construction projects of the Delta Plan. These massive engineering works include dams, locks, and storm surge barriers that protect the Netherlands from North Sea flooding.

The decline in religious participation and influence in Dutch society. Since the 1960s, the Netherlands has become increasingly secular, with fewer people regularly attending church or identifying as religious.

Foreign workers who came to the Netherlands in the 1960s and 1970s, mainly from Turkey and Morocco. They helped rebuild the Dutch economy after World War II and many stayed, contributing to Dutch multicultural society.
The capital and largest city of the Netherlands. Amsterdam is famous for its historic canals, museums like the Rijksmuseum, and its role as a major financial and cultural center in Europe.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland

cards.description: The main international airport of the Netherlands, located near Amsterdam. Schiphol is one of Europe's busiest airports and serves as a major hub for international travel and cargo.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland

cards.description: The second-largest city in the Netherlands and Europe's largest port. Rotterdam is a major center for international trade, shipping, and industry, with modern architecture alongside historic sites.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland

cards.description: The seat of government and third-largest city in the Netherlands. Den Haag is home to the Dutch parliament, government ministries, and international organizations like the International Court of Justice.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland

cards.description: The fourth-largest city in the Netherlands and a major university city. Utrecht is known for its historic center, the Dom Tower, and its central location making it a major transport hub.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland

cards.description: The urban area in the western Netherlands connecting Amsterdam, Rotterdam, The Hague, and Utrecht. The Randstad is the economic heart of the Netherlands, home to most of the population and economic activity.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland

cards.description: A large forested area in the eastern Netherlands. The Veluwe is popular for outdoor activities like hiking and cycling, and is home to wildlife including deer and wild boar.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland

cards.description: A chain of islands in the Wadden Sea along the northern coast of the Netherlands. These islands are known for their natural beauty, bird watching, and unique tidal landscape that's a UNESCO World Heritage site.
cards.subcategory: Geografie en de mensen van Nederland
